text:
And we are going to go
ahead and start right here. Welcome to our final session
of Silicon Valley and the US

government. I am thrilled to
introduce Dr. Casey Perley, who is the director
of the Army Applications Lab.

She's going to do more of
her background as we talk. It's a fascinating story,
especially for those

who have considered working
in the US government but aren't exactly sure
how they would start

or where they would start. I think we're going
to hear some of that. Some more of what you're
going to have to hear today

is the story of the unfolding
of an organization starting from scratch in
the US government,

particularly the army. And so please be thinking
about questions as well,

because it's a rich story. And so let's actually
start right into this.

Casey, how did you end up
working for, not only the US government, but the US Army?

So if you asked me about
15 years ago, what would I

be doing, I would
have told you that I was going to be a pediatric
oncologist in a children's

hospital somewhere. And clearly, my life took
a very different direction.

When I went to college,
I got in a research lab for the first time. And I had this realization
about my junior year of college

that if I saw a really
interesting case, my gut reaction would
be, I want to study this

and not I want to treat that. And that's probably a really
bad gut reaction for a doctor.

So I said, OK, well, I'm
going to go get my PhD. And I fell in love
with microbiology.

Specifically, I fell in love
with a book called The Hot Zone. Have you guys read The Hot
Zone or seen the movie?

It's about when Ebola came to
Reston, Virginia, in the 1980s.

And luckily, it was a strain
that only infected monkeys. Most people read that
book and are terrified.

I read that book
and went, aha, I have discovered what I
want to do with my life.

So I went and I got a PHD. And when I was done
with my PHD, I still really wanted to work on
hemorrhagic fever viruses.

And at the time, there were only
two real places you did that. It was the CDC in Atlanta, or
it was the United States Army's

Medical Research Institute
of Infectious Diseases at Fort Detrick in Maryland. Full disclosure, I'm
married to an army officer.

My husband was like,
there's more jobs for me in DC than Atlanta, because
I was moving ahead of him by a year.

I said, you damn right it is. And I went and I
got a postdoc there. And I spent 3 and 1/2 years
there wearing the biosafety 4

level spacesuit, had
the pneumatic air hose, held the hemorrhagic
fever viruses.

You have to get the equivalent
of a top secret clearance to be allowed to hold them. And I loved every minute of it.

But I was married to a
soldier, and soldiers move. And he's got command
of a battalion

at then Fort Hood,
now Fort Cavazos in Texas, which is about an hour
and a half outside of Austin. And I was like, I married
you because I liked you,

so I should probably
move with you. And there's no biosafety
level 4 is in Austin.

So what am I going to do? And I-- Army Futures Command was
just starting up at that time.

So the army did its biggest
reorganization since Vietnam. And it said, we are going to
put the people that do our tech

development, that write
the requirements for what we need to buy, and
make the concept of how we're going to fight.

We're going to put
them all in one org. And they're going to
iteratively improve each other. And along with Army Futures
Command standing up,

there was an organization
called Army Applications Lab. That was designed to help
non-traditional business inject

their technology
into that cycle. And I said, well, I need a job.

They're looking for scientists. This sounds like a fit. And I called them
up and I said, I

hear you're looking
for scientists. And they said, no, we're
looking for engineers. And I said, OK,
fair distinction.

But if you ever want to
experiment with soldiers,

you're going to
need somebody that knows how to write institutional
review board protocols and manage ethics approvals.

And I've done that-- I've been involved in
clinical trials, guys. And they said, you're
right, and they hired me.

And five years later,
I'm the director, and I've done zero
IRBs in my time at AAL.

OK, well, let's talk about that
journey over those five years as well. And would you
provide for all of us

a description of what AAL does? Sure. So army applications
lab mission is

to get the best technology into
the hands of the warfighters possible. There's a lot of orgs
that have that mission.

But our real niche
is that we do that by expanding the army's
access to our civil innovation

base, specifically
companies, in our case, but civil innovation base is
really companies in academia.

That civil innovation base is
a true competitive advantage

over Russia and China and
any of our other adversaries.

This is increasingly more
important because 60 years ago, about 2/3 of all research and
development spending in this

country was funded
by the government. Now it is 20%. And the technologies that
we increasingly need,

like cyber and
robotics and AI, are developing fastest in the
commercial sector, where there's

a lot of market pressures and
market feedback that's going on. So we need to figure
out how to align

the incentives for those
companies and their investors to want to come work with
the DOD that admittedly has

very protracted acquisition
timelines and is not the easiest to work with and is especially
hard to get end user feedback

to create those
iterative feedback cycles that you get
if you're taking a product to commercial market.

But five years ago, we
didn't know any of that. What was happening
five years ago? We just got the mission, go make
it easier for non-traditionals

and academia to work with us. And in the first two years
under our first director,

two things happened. One, we consolidated
our mission to be that non-traditional space.

There are other organizations
within Army Futures Command that are doing fantastic
on that academia mission.

They own that. We divested of that so we could
put our focus on companies. We were also originally
supposed to have a maker space,

where companies could come
in and build prototypes if they didn't have
certain types of equipment in their own facilities.

That got scrapped, too. So we just went for
this, we're going to figure out how to
make it attractive

for non-traditional businesses
to work with the government. We were fortunate. So we're located at a place
called the Capital Factory

in Austin. It is a tech accelerator
incubator, co-working space.

It's got a venture
capital arm attached. But the Air Force's innovation
arm, AF works, is there.

Defense Innovation
Unit was there. So we could learn
from their lessons. And they were our neighbors.

So we could go ask
some questions. And we avoided making the
same mistakes that they made.

And not to say they were
mistakes, they tried things and they didn't work. So we knew not to
try them again, because trying
things the same way

and expecting different
results, I think is the definition of Insanity. Well, if I can ask then, what
were some of those things

that you learned? So DIU, originally DIU
1.0, had this thesis

that they could go
out to Silicon Valley and find all the cool tech and
take it back to the Pentagon and be like, I have found fire.

You would like fire, right? You would like to buy fire. What do you mean? It's going to take
you two to three years

to get it in the budget. It's fire. So what we learned is that you
need to start with a problem,

that if you start
with a problem, it is easier to align
all of the stakeholders.

The people that are
going to buy it, at the end of the
day, the people who are going to write the
requirements document

help the people buy it
at the end of the day. The scientists and
engineers who are going to help you get
through your authority

to operate on an army
network or your airworthiness release that you need
to fly on an army range.

You can line all that
up at the beginning if you know what the problem is. And that's going to make
it a little bit more

likely or a lot more
likely, we think, for the technology to cross. You guys have heard of the
Valley of Death, right?

To cross that Valley of Death. The other thing we learned
really early on, kind

of simultaneously with all
the other organizations, was don't go out with a phone
book requirement of like,

I need it to be this
super specific thing, because what you're
going to get is

a lot of really great contract
research organizations that can come in and build
down to your specifications,

but you're not going to get
a lot of commercial ingenuity and creativity.

If you go out with the
broadest possible problem, things like how do I resupply
field artillery in the field

faster, you're going to
bring in companies who've never worked on field
artillery before

and are going to look
at your problem and say, you don't need a robotic arm.

You're literally doing the
inventory management on paper still. This is 2020.

We can automate all of
this and save you time. And by the way,
your paper is not going to disintegrate
in the rain anymore.

If you do that too,
because that doesn't look like fun for that
poor ammo supply sergeant. So start with a problem,
make that problem

as broad as possible to
allow industry to innovate. That was really the core
of the first two years,

just figuring out
how to do that. And like any good
government organization, waiting for your turn to get
into the Congressional Budget

because I'm not joking when I
say it takes two to three years, and we had to wait it
out to get a budget.

So at this point, you
have left a laboratory.

You have entered
government service. You are working
through these problems.

We now have the
benefit of, of course, the hindsight five years ago. But tell us a little
bit about what that was

like in this new organization. And in fact, if
you would, give us three adjectives or descriptors,
what was it like back then?

It was confusing. We didn't really
know what we were doing because we were designed
to try to hack the system.

And the moment you think
you found efficiencies, suddenly you're in a place
where nobody's necessarily been before, hasn't
been in a while,

and you don't really
know what you're doing. It was exciting. And it still is.

There is a lot of passion
on our team for what we do.

People are excited
to come to work. And there was a
lot of uncertainty

because we had a model. But we had no clue if
it was going to work, and we had no clue
how we were going

to prove it was working,
because, at that point we'd gotten money kind
of here and there,

one-offs designed to do this
project, do that project.

They weren't done
yet, so nobody knew if they were going to make
anything that the army wanted.

So all we did was
tell our story. And at some point,
that story was going to not be good enough anymore.

We were going to
have to give numbers, and we didn't know how we
were going to measure it and if the numbers
would be good. So yeah, there was
that aspect, too.

So it was confusing,
it was exciting. And? It was uncertain. Uncertain. And so here you are
working with those

in the government who are
deciding what to do with you. What were companies-- how
were they reacting to you?

In particular, if you
could talk to us about what your early interactions with
Silicon Valley were like?

Skepticism. I mean, once again,
I think we benefited from Defense Innovation
Unit and AFWERX

having been around before
us, because people weren't like, what the heck are you?

They're like, OK, you look
familiar, you seem familiar. But DIU and AFWERX weren't
that much older than us,

so their early-- their returns
were still in the early days as well. There was a lot of
uncertainty about how

they were going to turn out. So there was that. I'll say this,
early on, companies

were willing to work with us. Investors were willing
to work with us. But it was a very cautious
wait-and-see approach.

And we knew we had to try to
hit on some of our first couple projects, or this really
wasn't going to work.

So to add some richness
to this, tell us about some of those
projects, the early wins.

So one of them was-- What are the early,
early mistakes? We had those too. So one of those was that field
artillery autonomous resupply

project I told you guys about. We thought-- I think if you
asked our cross-functional team

directors, so in the army, there
are some major modernization priority efforts
that we need to do.

And they have put
one star generals in charge of cross-functional
teams designed to get after those.

So the cross-functional
team director for our fires and
the acquisition guy, the guy that's going
to buy the fires,

I think if you ask them what
we were going to get out of field artillery autonomous
resupply, they would have said, I want little mini
autonomous tracked vehicles

with robot arms running around
the battlefield and like, putting ammo in the
back of field artillery.

What we learned there is the way
artillery works is they fire,

and then they immediately scoot. So it's called shoot and scoot,
because the moment they fired,

the enemy can do counter-battery
fire and try to hit them. They often resupply in between
the first location where

they shot and the
second location where they're going to shoot. So if you really
want to speed up how quickly they can fire
from that second location,

you can resupply them faster. And you don't need
little vehicles running around the
battlefield to do that.

You need ammunition
management that tells battalion Commanders
what crews are low without them having a report.

And with artillery, you have
to read all these numbers off the round and plug it
into our fire control software

to allow things to fire. You need systems that
automatically do that, and you can save a
whole lot of time.

So that was an early one. I'm going to call
it a quasi-win. We had two companies that
built that system for inventory

management I described. They moved on to a
program of record. We actually made a
new program of record
in the army for this technology. We helped write the requirement. We identified the tech.

The companies moved on
to the program of record. I think by now the
requirements should be science,

so it might be the army's
newest program of record. But the companies didn't
make it all the way through.

The army, at the end of the
day, for the final thing, went a different direction.

So while I'm really proud of
the work we did for the army,

and while I did show
investors, hey, we can actually create acquisition
programs, those companies

didn't see the big reward
at the end of the day. So it's not as much of a win as
I would have hoped it would be.

Another great one is
we had a project where we put data scientists forward. So one of the problems when you
think back to counterterrorism

days is you would conduct a
raid on an enemy location, and you would get a lot
of intelligence out of it,

often written computer
drives, et cetera. How do we go through
that quicker so we

can exploit the info inside? We did a project involving data
scientists to help with that.

That has led to a lot-- the
army really thinking differently about how it employs
data scientists, where

it should put them, all
the things they can do. It's actually gone really
great for the company. So that was an early win.

And then we have-- it's
going to sound so silly. We made an electric
wheelbarrow, guys.

But tunnel operations
are a thing. And in tunnels,
sometimes our engineers

are asked to carry hundreds of
pounds of breaching equipment. It is not easy to carry
that through a tunnel.

So we built like
an electric cart that could carry all of this. It can also be used
to medevac casualties

down seven flights of stairs,
only needing two people, instead a hell of a lot more. And it can be used-- you can
mount different payloads on it,

so you don't have to carry
it, serve as a shield. That's gone on to great life.

There are a lot of
units using it now, but it didn't get there
through programmer record. It got there through
Congressional ads

from its congressmen. So I think if you'd asked AAL
five years ago what we thought

you would get out of
us, we would say, yeah, we're going to do
all this tech, we're going to come up with
a model, and we're

going to build a
playbook and how you can transition technology. And I think the biggest
lesson I have is

that each time we take on a
project and we transition it, it is bespoke, it is
specific, it needs

its own individual effort. There is no playbook that I
can give somebody and say, here's how to get
your technology

across the Valley of
Death, because it's going to look different every time. That's a big insight.

That looks like it was hard won. It was. And it was a little sad, because
when you think about scale,

I don't-- I want AAL to work
itself out of a job.

I want the army
and the government to get so good at working with
businesses that are not prime.

So think about primes,
it's not that they're big, it's that they've structured
their whole business model around working
with the government.

So they understand
our budget cycles, they understand our
acquisition timelines, and they're built
to absorb that.

So I want the government to get
good at working with businesses that are designed to be in
the commercial market space.

They're not designed to work
on our standard timelines. I want us to get so good
at transitioning technology

that if you meet the army need,
there's not a question of if, when, it's like, of
course, here's the pathway.

So I'm sad that I don't
appear to be working myself out of a job yet. Well, tell us about
the team back then.

So again, we're looking
at the story of how this unfolded maybe five years ago.

What did the team look like? I went to a conference last week
where it was all S&P leaders.

And they said, this person
on the panel was like, don't hire for the
job, hire talent.

And you can kind of shape
the job around that talent. And it was so insightful
to me because I realized

that's how AAL stood up. We are a 35 person organization,
24 government civilians,

11 military spread
across active duty, activated National Guard,
and activated reservists.

And at the beginning, if
you had a science background or a background in acquisition
or had civilian project

management skills, we hired you. And we were going to figure
out exactly what you were going to do when you got on board.

And that's kind of how we
built the organization. And I realized we did exactly
what that conference said.

We hired talent and
just figured out where it fit and started
building our business model around that.

And then eventually,
some of those skill sets weren't needed or
weren't needed as much, and they went on and found
other really cool things

either at venture
capital firms or actually as engineers and companies now. But the rest of us
like, kind of kept on.

It's interesting, if you
look at our civilians, three broad flavors.

We have our project managers
and our contracts guys. So these are the guys that do
cost, schedule, performance,

are they are they
meeting deliverables? I have some people that have
come from army, acquisition army

project management,
but the bulk of them are coming with commercial
project management certificates, having done project management
in the commercial space.

I've got a tech team,
which is where I started. I've had five jobs
in five years. I started on the tech team.

I built out our review pipeline. I published our
first solicitation.

Those were the first
two things I did in lab. So we've got a couple of PhDs. And then we've got
our corporate team.

These are-- we have two
of the 10 entrepreneurs and residents in
all of the army. I've got commercial
engagement analysts

who come to us from corporate
accelerators and venture capital firms who do deep corporate due
diligence on these companies,

both in terms of are they
stable, but also in terms of have they taken
money knowingly

or unknowingly from a VC with
ties to countries of concern.

Do they have any people
on this proposal? Is that I need to
create a mitigation plan

around to ensure that
information doesn't get back to our adversaries. Then we got our ops
guys, who are just

really good at reminding
us we're still in the army, and we still have to do
all the army things that let us interface with the army.

So those are the broad spectrum
of civilians that we have. So the real motley crew, I'll
say maybe a third to half

serve in the National
Guard or our veterans. The other ones of us, nope,
this is our first foray

into government. And it's really
fun, because I get to watch those civilians teach
our veterans and our military

about all these cool, different
ways of doing things or about science or about
the corporate world. And then I get to watch
our military tell them

that it's like a jet
turbine engine inside a tank and watch them get
equally excited

and have their minds be like,
wow, I didn't know that. So it's fun to
watch that exchange.

So you learned over
time to speak army. I did. And we can tell you, you are
all in on the government speak.

And part of that is learning
also how to speak Silicon Valley and how to speak tech.

Tell us about that
process for you. So for us, hiring and firing
criteria is your ability to translate,
whether that be tech

into non-technical language,
corporate into something tech folks in military will
understand, or military

in into one or the others. One of our hiring questions
for our scientists

is tell us about your
research project. Tell a sixth grader about
your research project.

And if they can't get the
second part of the question, it's a government interview. So we do have to finish out
all the rest of the questions,

but it doesn't matter. If you can't figure out how to
go to that sixth grader level,

it doesn't work. We ask similar questions of
our military and our project managers. What is that translation like?

So if you can come in able to
translate at least one way, we know you have the
ability to think like that,

distill concepts down, and we
can figure out how to teach you, how to translate the
other sections you're not
how you measure innovation? That's a good one.

So think about a
grocery store, right. If you own a grocery
store, you have to make a decision
on what you're

going to put on the shelves. So you're going to monitor how
often somebody buys Cocoa Puffs

versus Cinnamon Toast Crunch
versus Rice Krispies, which are my favorite, but definitely
not my daughter's favorite.

She's two. So, she's still not really
on the cereal bandwagon. But if chocolate, she's it.

We have to figure out how
to do that for innovation. So we took a look
at what matters

to Silicon Valley, what
matters to the people that invest in these companies. We took a look at what matters
to Congress because they've

given us our budget. We've taken a look at
what matters to soldiers. And we've come up
with some numbers

that we think tell us what
the equivalent of what cereal to buy.

Tell us about those. What are they? So here's the challenge for
an innovation organization.

You are satisfying all of
the different groups I just mentioned. You're satisfying Congress and
army senior leaders, companies

and their investors. So you really need
two sets of metrics. Another really crucial
kind of insight we had

is that we thought there would
be one return on investment metric to rule them
all, that I would find

some holy grail of a number
or a scale that would say, this is my return on
investment for every project.

It doesn't work that way,
at least in our experience. So what we started doing
is building business cases

for all of our projects. They don't look
like a business case if you're an MBA,
because it's not profit

equals revenue minus cost. It's what is the military
utility for the cost. Am I getting something faster?

Am I getting fourfold
greater coverage? Am I saving money? Am I saving lives?

And then based on what that
military return on investment is, then you figure
out, well, what

are the numbers I need to hit
to show that I'm giving you that return? And we have to do it on a
project by project basis.

The next thing that
we have to look at is, what is transitioning? What is our transition rate? How much is moving on?

And then of what moves
on, why does it stop? Like what makes it all the way
through the funnel, what stops

halfway through, et cetera. We have to look at how
many of the companies

we're working with have
limited to no DOD experience. And after us, how many
of them are going on

to do more business with the
government, because our mission is to expand access. So how well are we doing that?

And that's kind of what we
look at on the gov side. On the commercial
side, what we're looking at is, how many
states are we working with?

Because once again,
what you would expect the highest
concentration of companies to be in states with
major tech hubs.

If those are the only states
that are giving me companies, we're clearly
missing some things. We're looking at how much
money are they raising?

Are they raising more
or less after they've been on contract with us to
try to get after the oblique measurement of are you still
competitive to raise money.

And what is the time
to your next contract and how much is
that for to start to get after some of
the investors concerns

about what is going to be
the timeline for return on their investment?

So of course, in
government, one of the most predictable and difficult things
is justifying your budget.

So here, you have
these measures that are a little different than
what others are measured by.

Tell us about broadly
how you've worked through the bureaucracy, the
big organization, the resource

process. So we're fortunate, I
report to the chief of staff

of Army Futures Command,
who's a two-star, but then my big boss
is a four-star general.

He is one of three people
in the army that can sign requirements, documents. So this gives us not only
top cover and the ability

to try something
different, but when you found the thing that's
going to save lives or save

$1 billion, and you're running
into bureaucracy at the action officer level, there
are people you can call

that can try to break that. And that's really critical. So we were lucky to have that
type of advocacy and top cover

that got us about a $25
million budget to begin with. We're really good at
getting matching funds and using other people's money.

So we move about $50 million
through our lab annually.

But yeah, there was just a
lot of advocacy on top cover. And then the early
projects, the early stories

were compelling, so people
didn't turn that spigot off. And now we've reached
a five years in,

we've had a budget for three
years, where we actually have some solid numbers. And we took a big step during
South by Southwest this year,

where I stood up in front
of a room full of 80 people, including people from
Congress and industry

and the innovation arms
of major corporations. And I said, here is
our report, here's

how we're measuring
ourselves, here's how we did against
those measures.

Tell us what I missed. Tell me if you think
this is good enough. Tell us what we got wrong. Here's your red pen. And we've gotten such
good feedback on that.

I've gotten investors
saying, yes, these are the numbers I'd like,
but I'd like it broken down to understand at
what stage of venture

backing these companies
are, because that's going to inform me
about certain things. Or I've gotten them saying,
I want to understand,

once it's transitioned,
what pathways look like. And that's actually led us
to some critical insights about there might be
different levers we

need to pull to get some
technology across the line. So while at first
when I started,

it was really frustrating
that nobody could tell me, here's how you measure
yourself and here's how when

you've done a good job. By putting out a document and
starting the conversation,

it's been really
fun to have people come back and be very engaged
and give us ideas on ways

to improve that. So I think that's also
another lesson I've learned. Don't give people a
blank sheet of paper, they're going to give
you blank paper back.

Give people paper that
has writing on it, and they'll definitely
give you your feedback.

Can you tell us a few points
of feedback in particular that perhaps you received from
investors or for companies

that changed the
way you do business? Yeah. So one of the beautiful things
about being in Capital Factory

is that we run into
companies every day when we're eating our lunch up
or going to the little snack kiosk.

So our whole
business model at AAL is built around
three principles. Access-- how do we
recreate access?

Companies get in the
commercial sector by giving them access to
people who are going to buy, at the end of the day,
the soldiers, those end

users who provide the feedback. How do they learn
about solicitations when they're not
actively looking to do business with the DOD?

Transparency. So wherever possible, giving
them a business case up front. So about how many
is the army going to buy on about what timeline
for about how much money?

So that they don't make faulty
assumptions in their business and assume we're going to buy
more faster for more money.

They've abandoned their
commercial trajectory. We can't deliver on
the timeline they need, the company goes under.

And speed to capital. We can't take nine months to
deliver a contract because it's

delaying development
time for the army, and companies can't wait nine
months for the first check. So how we do
contracting quickly?

We can get up to $3 million on
contract within about 90 days of a solicitation closing. So that's down selection
and all the contracting.

But also, how do you structure
payments inside that contract? So companies don't
have to wait a month

and then invoice and then
wait another couple of weeks to get that first check. So we do some deliverable
based payments.

We'll sometimes put one at
the end of the first week if there's a lot
of travel involved, so that we can
ideally beat payroll,

beat a travel card so companies
are limited in the amount their out of pocket,
working with government.

Those are the lessons
that founded AAL. So a couple more questions and
then we'll turn it to Q&A. First

off, if, let's say, that a
senior leader in the Department

of Defense came to
you and said, we're going to set up a new
organization that creates value

in new Ways, you might call
it an innovation organization, you might call it
something else, what advice

would you give after all
these years of building this? Give them at least
five years before you

evaluate if they're successful. They're going to go through
a lot of fits and starts. They're going to go through
a lot of reorganizations.

They're not going to have money. They're not going
to have people. Give them time to
figure themselves out.

And the second thing I would say
is don't be overly prescriptive. We really benefited from leaders
who look to us to tell them

what they AAL should be. And when we went to them and
said, we're this, not that. They listened.

So giving those-- that team
the flexibility to say,

you asked me to solve
this problem this way, I'm going to solve
your problem, but I'm going to do it another way.

That's OK. And lastly, what would you
hope that AAL is known for?

Well, it depends
on the audience. In the commercial
space, I want us to be

known as business-friendly. I want us to be known as the
place that you want to come, when you need to figure out
how to work with the army.

On the army side,
I want us to be known for where the people
that get you tech fast.

But in order to
get you tech fast, I've got to be
commercially friendly. Otherwise, those
companies aren't going to want to come do business.

So they are
inextricably related. OK. Well, let's go ahead and
open this up to questions.

Bring around the mic. And you won't hear
your voice on the mic, but it picks it up
on the recording.

And ultimately, what

or so and make the rounds

and do engagements. But AAL, we are an
Austin-based organization.

I do work for the government. So for governmental

Did I dance around
that nicely enough? OK. When they were deciding--
when Army Futures Command was

standing up, they made a really
smart decision, a very unarmed decision that they
were not going to put us on a military post,
behind wire, behind guards.

And they launched a search for
cities where they could base us.

And at the end of
the day, it came down to Austin, Boston,
Massachusetts, and Research Triangle Park.

And while I can't comment
on what ultimately led them to choose Austin,
that was a decision up

at the Secretary of the
Army level before I joined. What I can say is to me,
Austin is a nexus a lot

of great academia. There is a good startup
culture in industry, though maybe not as robust as,
say, here in Silicon Valley.

We're also about
an hour and a half away from a major military
base, which does provide--

which is for Cavazos
or formerly known as Fort Hood, which
provides like retirement

services for our soldiers. And there's a
National Guard base where we can all get our IDs. And they didn't have to
build that infrastructure.

But we also heavily leveraged
Fort Cavazos for soldier touch points and experimentation.

So having that unit
really close by has led to a lot of great
synergies that I think

would have been harder to have
happen had it gone to Boston. Research Triangle
Park, look, I'm biased,

I did my PhD at Duke, right. Like that was home
for six years. It's where I met my husband. But to me, there's
more biomed there.

Austin is a little bit more
hardware software focused, which is more the area
that AFC is interested in.

But what ultimately led to

on why it's a good fit.

I have a question about
the have you integrate these startups to
like, could you

please walk us through
this from solicitation part up until integration
to work with you?

And what do you look for
in the quality of the team? Some-- as startups,
there are various stages.

There are smaller ones there. As long as there's
a fit with the tech that you're looking
for, how does that work?

And also, after getting
through the process, do you expect the startups to
be located close by or like,

do any R&D with you or any
facilities for experimentations that you provide to the startups
to get it commercialized?

Great questions. So one, we don't care
where you're located. We have companies in 33
states that we work with.

We will try to find a
military base near you for you to do your
soldier touch points. But if you are working on a
weapon system like HIMARS,

there's really no need. There's not a lot
of those bases. So you might have to fly,
let's put it that way.

So when we release a
solicitation, it's going to be, broadly speaking,
one of two flavors.

One is going to be, I need
a widget, I need a thing.

Because I'm trying to
solve a very specific gap or trying to go on to
an existing platform,

I'm going to constrain you a
little bit about form factor or whatever you need. I'm probably going to select to
three companies, each of whom

take a different
technical approach. The other flavor
of solicitation is what we call a cohort project.

Sometimes we'll get
asked to solve problems that involve so many different
technical areas that there's

no one company that can be best
in breed across all of them. So instead of finding
one company that's really good in one area and
pretty good in the rest,

we tell companies
we only want you to bring part of the solution. And we'll put 5 to 15
companies on contract.

And we'll run them through a
12-week program that exposes them to the problem
and each other. And when we down select to do
them in viable product build,

about five of those
will come through, and they'll typically have
complementary technologies. So that if you merge
them all together,

you get a complete system. Or like if you merge four
of the five together, you get a complete system. If you take this guy out, then
you get those four out of five.

Does that make sense? So once they're on contract,
then whether it be 5 to 15

or just 2 to 3 that are a little
bit more competitive in nature, typically the first week,
somewhere in the first 1

to 3 weeks, we are going to
take you to meet soldiers if that's relevant or
scientists if that's relevant.

you don't need to
talk to soldiers. You need to talk to the guys
that own the RCV, the Robotic

Combat Vehicles. So we're going to take you to
see those, and let you crawl all over the vehicle, right.

So from there, we'll typically
meet with you once a month-ish. But let's say you need
an authority to operate,

we are going to walk
you through that. We might be calling-- you
might be calling us a lot more. If you're trying to get your
air worthiness released,

there might be a lot
more hand-holding there. And once you've gotten it, go
back to those monthly reports.

We don't own any testing
facilities or anything like that, but the army does. So, for example, we had a
company, needs to figure out

where it's going to place
a sensor on something. There is a prototype
integration facility 30 minutes

from their location. So we got the access so
they could crawl around the thing they had a
place to sensor on.

And they figured it out
within like 45 minutes. It was great. We also don't have
testing facilities,

but we do keep a list of the
most common type companies need. So we can just kind of say near
you, here's some we know about.

There might be others
because we're the government, we can't mandate
you to go anywhere. But if we are going to
collude six companies together

into one thing, we will
pay for the collusion and the demonstration
typically on an army range,
but sometimes commercial. It depends. Does that answer your questions? It does. Thank you very much. Awesome.

Hi. Thank you for your
time this afternoon. Many are actually in Joe

hacking for defense. I'm also-- yeah,
I'm from Maryland. My uncle is at Fort Detrick. My parents both work in DC.

to move out to Austin. I agree. I miss Fort Detrick,

So we're working with a country
in South America called Guyana,

and we're hoping to
essentially establish a tech startup to win
infrastructure contracts from the local government.

But Guyana has essentially
no private sector, and so we're in
absolutely new territory.

We would be establishing
the precedent for what private-public
partnerships look like in this country.

And so I know this is a
very peripheral question, but from your experience
working in this area and the American
government, how do

you think we might approach
creating this new form factor? And what advice do
you have for us?

So we actually-- we
have a company that has created a very unique
public-private partnership that I think has some
interesting lessons.

They are a company that
makes rocket motors, so they needed land
with which they could

shoot things long distances. And in the middle
of Texas, there are places with the FAA
allowances, let's say,
to let them do that. But land can be expensive.

The city near them, they
didn't really need the land, they just needed
the water rights

for the water and
the water table, a couple hundred feet below,
that wouldn't be disrupted

by anything flying over it. So they actually entered
into a pretty cool public-private partnership
where the company

was able to create a
private test range in return for the state keeping
the water rights. So what I would say
is, as you think

about public-private
partnerships, think about what you really
need and the interests

of the public
government, and you might be able to find some
really interesting intersections

like that particular
company did. For us, one of the
things that I often

tell congressional delegations
that come through our lab, when they always say,
what can you do for me? I'm like, it's not for me.

But in this country, there is a
shortage of commercial testing infrastructure, especially
for companies with payloads

that go boom or bang. What's happening is
that's delaying companies

being able to try
things out, or they're getting to their
official amy test not having as much range
time as they should,

and it doesn't go well,
and it causes delays. So I kind of pushed
back on Congress that if you want to
keep energizing this,

I would say, what
are ways that you could incentivize the creation
of these types of testing

ranges? So for me, I'm not
asking anything for AAL.

This is all about the
challenges our companies face. And that type of framing I think
resonates a lot with leaders.

So as you think through how
you approach that government, it's not about what
you need as a company,

it's about what's going
to help their people. And I think that framing
might do you some good.
